subject: RE: [junit] where there has abstract method in interface
msgSnippet: As far as I can remember the appearance of the abstract specification for the methods in the junit.framework.Test interface was just a mistake. Kent Beck Three
messageBody:
As far as I can remember the appearance of the abstract specification for
the methods in the junit.framework.Test interface was just a mistake.

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of J. B. Rainsberger
> Sent: Wednesday, June 22, 2005 11:00 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] where there has abstract method in interface
>
> David Saff wrote:
> > J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> >
> > > hxd07 wrote:
> > > > public interface Test {
> > > > public abstract int countTestCases();
> > > > public abstract void run(TestResult result);
> > > > }
> > >
> > > Here, the abstract keyword does nothing useful. It's
> likely that when
> > > Kent and/or Erich created this class, Eclipse added the
> "abstract"
> > > keyword for them and they never bothered to remove it.
> > >
> > > For that matter, the methods don't need to be marked
> "public" either.
> >
> > There is one use to leaving the superfluous "public
> abstract" modifiers:
> > if you decide to change an interface into an abstract class, or vice
> > versa, it's one less textual step you need to perform.
> >
> > Doesn't JUnit predate Eclipse?
>
> A fine point. It might therefore have been Visual Age for
> Java throwing
> that stuff in. I seem to recall that it did that. :)
> --
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com
> Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
>
